Figure 1 shows a model of a signal transduction cascade, initiated by the binding of a ligand to the transmembrane receptor protein <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></math>.

Figure 1. Model of signal transduction cascade incorporating protein <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></math>

A <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> mutation changes the shape of the extracellular domain of transmembrane receptor protein <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> produced by the cell. Which of the following predictions is the most likely consequence of the mutation?

choices.label: Production of activated molecule 1 will stop, but production of activated molecules 2 and 3 will continue.
The molecule that normally binds to protein <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will no longer attach, deactivating the cellular response.
The molecule that normally binds to protein <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will not enter the cell, thus no cellular response will occur.
Since protein <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is embedded in the membrane, the mutation will be silent and not affect the cellular response.

content.answer: The molecule that normally binds to protein <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will no longer attach, deactivating the cellular response.
